repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Punjab Private Sector
            Groundwater Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Punjab Private Sector
            Groundwater Development Project is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as substantial, Bank performance as satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance as satisfactory. This is one of the few
            projects in the water sector in Pakistan that has been
            completed within the original credit closing date. Key
            project components exceeded project targets and the project
            objective was largely achieved. Lessons learned from the
            project include: 1) The quality of social mobilization and
            after-care capacity building, to a large extent, determine
            the quality and sustainability of farmers'
            organizations (FO). 2) Key project staff should be on board
            by project approval. 3) A national water policy must guide
            the preparation of a groundwater regulation framework. 4)
            The procurement process for key works, goods, and
            consultants services required during the first year of the
            project should be at an advanced stage by project
            negotiations, so that disbursement commence immediately
            after effectiveness. 5) Women's involvement enhances
            sustainability of FOs by facilitating conflict resolution
            and improving quality of decisions regarding location of
            irrigation structures.

5081096.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Punjab Private Sector
            Groundwater Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objectives of the Punjab
            Private Sector Groundwater Development Project are to
            increase the scope and productivity of Punjab's
            irrigation and drainage subsector and increase farmers'
            incomes. The specific objectives are to: (a) redefine
            Government's role in groundwater development and
            provide assistance to facilitate change; (b) develop a
            monitoring program and regulatory framework to ensure
            sustainable use of the groundwater resources; (c) develop
            sustainable farmers' organizations; (d) increase
            beneficiaries' incomes and alleviate poverty; (e)
            rationalize public expenditure on operation and management
            of the irrigation and drainage systems as well as increase
            the recovery of public expenditures on irrigation
            infrastructure; and (f) avoid environmental hazard of saline
            water intrusion into fresh groundwater aquifers. The project
            covering a large part of fresh groundwater Salinity Control
            and Reclamation Project (SCARP) areas in Punjab will be
            implemented over a period of five years. The major
            components are: (a) disinvestment of SCARP tubewells; (b)
            development of a groundwater monitoring and regulatory
            framework; (c) improvement of irrigation conveyance
            facilities; (d) prevention of saline groundwater intrusion
            in fresh aquifers; (e) monitoring and evaluation of the
            project; and (f) project management, and technical
            assistance and training.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Privatization of Groundwater
            Development in SCARP Areas Project - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is a supplementary note to an
            environmental assessment for the Privatization of
            Groundwater Development in SCARP (Salinity Control and
            Reclamation Programme) Areas Project in India, which aims to
            increase the scope and productivity of Punjab's
            irrigation and drainage subsector and to increase farmers
            incomes while installing tubewells and monitoring
            groundwater to prevent waterlogging and saline intrusion.
            This note covers social as well as environmental aspects of
            the project, although this abstract mainly focuses on
            detailing mitigations to environmental impacts. To prevent
            the closure of SCARP tubewells from reducing irrigation
            water supply and thus decreasing land use, the
            diversion/regulatory structures of the canal system will be
            rehabilitated. Land use permanently reduced by installing
            tubewells and surface drains will lead to decreased land
            productivity, but this is insignificant when compared to the
            impact on the total project area. Dust, smoke, and noise
            generated by construction machinery will be reduced by using
            good engineering practices. Diesel operated tubewells may
            result in air pollution, but the pollutants expected to be
            dispersed are half that presently generated by privatized
            tubewells (PTWs). To help reduce polarization between
            farmers and government agencies, farmers organizations will
            be developed as institutions, and community tubewells (CTWs)
            and water courses will be communally developed.
